article.title: Aging and Estrogen Status: A Possible Endothelium-Dependent Vascular Coupling Mechanism in Bone Remodeling
funding: National Institutes of Health R01 HL077224
National Aeronautics and Space Administration NNX08AQ62G
Jane Adams Edmonds Endowed Ph.D. Fellowship
article.abstract: Bone loss with aging and menopause may be linked to vascular endothelial dysfunction.

sections.introduction: Postmenopausal osteoporosis is characterized by pronounced bone resorption.
sections.methods: Young (4 mon old) and old (22 mon old) virgin female Fischer-344 rats were obtained from the vendor (National Institute of Aging colony, Harlan, Indianapolis, IN) and divided into six groups: 1) young intact (n = 10), 2) old intact (n = 11), 3) young OVX (n = 10), 4) old OVX (n = 9), 5) young OVX+E2 (n = 11), and 6) old OVX+E2 (n = 10).
sections.results: Body mass (Table 1) was higher in old vs. young intact animals.
sections.discussion: The purpose of this study was to determine whether estrogen status affects endothelium-dependent vasodilation in the femoral diaphyseal principal nutrient artery, and whether these putative changes in vascular endothelial function are associated with alterations in trabecular bone volume.

experimental_factors.tissue: femoral principal nutrient artery, distal femoral metaphysis
experimental_factors.tissue_raw: femoral principal nutrient artery, distal femoral metaphysis

article.insights_summary: Estrogen status affects endothelium-dependent vasodilation in the femoral diaphyseal principal nutrient artery, and these changes are associated with alterations in trabecular bone volume.
